required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Phase II Study of Anlotinib Combined With Penpulimab in Subjects With Gynecological Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: A Single-arm, Open-label, Multi-cohort, Multi-center Phase II Clinical Study of Anlotinib Combined With Penpulimab in the Treatment of Recurrent or Metastatic Gynecological Cancer

lead_sponsor.agency: Sichuan Cancer Hospital and Research Institute

clinical_study.source: Sichuan Cancer Hospital and Research Institute

brief_summary.textblock: This is a single-arm, open-label, phase II clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of penpulimab combined with anlotinib in subjects with gynecological cancer, including 23 ovarian cancer，37 endometrial cancer，26 cervical cancer.

primary_outcome.description: Percentage of Participants Achieving Complete Response (CR) and Partial Response (PR)

secondary_outcome.description: PFS defined as the time from randomization until the first documented progressive disease (PD) or death from any cause.
Time from tumor first assessment to CR or PR to first assessment to PD (Progressive Disease) or death from any cause
Percentage of Participants Achieving Complete Response (CR) and Partial Response (PR) and Stable Disease (SD).

OS defined as the time from randomization to death from any cause. Participants who do not die at the end of the extended follow-up period, or were lost to follow-up during the study, were censored at the last date they were known to be alive.

arm_group.description: Penpulimab 200 mg IV on Day 1 of each 21-day cycle plus Anlotinib capsules 12mg given orally in fasting conditions , once daily in 21-day cycle (14 days on treatment from Day 1-14, 7 days off treatment from Day 15-21)

intervention.description: Penpulimab is a humanized monoclonal antibody targeting programmed cell death-1 (PD-1), which prevents PD-1 from binding to PD-L1 and PD-L2 receptors on tumor cell surface, restores T cell activity, thus enhancing immune response and has potential to treat various types of tumors.
A multi-target receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor

overall_official.affiliation: Sichuan Cancer Hospital and Research Institute

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Sichuan Cancer Hospital and Research Institute
